statement:
The *product rule* states that if $f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$
and $g:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ are functions in one variable
both differentiable at a point $x_0$, then the derivative of the product
of the two functions, denoted $f\cdot g$, at $x_0$ is given by
$$\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}\left(f\cdot g\right)(x_0) = f(x_0)g'(x_0) + f'(x_0)g(x_0).$$

Generalized Product Rule
------------------------

More generally, for differentiable functions $f_1, f_2,\ldots,f_n$ in
one variable, all differentiable at $x_0$, we have $$\begin{aligned}
D(f_1\cdots f_n)(x_0)=\sum_{i=1}^n\left(f_i(x_0)\cdots f_{i-1}(x_0)\cdot Df_i(x_0)\cdot f_{i+1}(x_0)\cdots f_n(x_0)\right).\end{aligned}$$

Also see .

### Example {#example .unnumbered}

The derivative of $x\ln|x|$ can be found by application of this rule.
Let $f(x) = x, g(x) = \ln|x|$, so that $f(x)g(x) = x\ln|x|$. Then
$f'(x) = 1$ and $g'(x) = \frac{1}{x}$. Therefore, by the product rule,

$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}(x\ln|x|) & = & f(x)g'(x) + f'(x)g(x) \\
& = & \frac{x}{x} + 1\cdot\ln|x| \\
& = & \ln|x| + 1\end{aligned}$$
